Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
NSF Postdoctoral Fellowships in Biology combine research and training components to prepare young scientists for careers in biology and require a plan to broaden participation of groups under-represented in science and engineering. The fellowships enhance NSF efforts to diversify the STEM workforce now and in the future. This fellowship to Mercedes Burns supports research on reproduction in insects and how different reproduction strategies evolve in different environments. The host institution for this fellowship is San Diego State University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Marshal Hedin. The Fellow is broadening her scientific horizons also through a research collaboration with scientists in Japan. The main training goal is to achieve mastery of genomic sequencing techniques to be used in identifying population-level genetic variation.


The research investigates the role of the ratio of males to females in evolution of mating systems in two species of harvestmen, the insects commonly known as daddy-longlegs. Effective male/female ratios may drive evolutionary change in the reproductive structures and mating systems of species by altering selection over the control of mating rate of each gender. In these species, reproduction proceeds with or without male fertilization and female-biased populations of these species are common in high-latitude and altitude marginal habitats. The research goals are to 1) elucidate mechanisms producing the geographic distribution of female-biased populations by reconstructing the colonization of marginal habitats using molecular markers and 2) examine the effects of a long-term female-biased ratio on female fecundity, male morphology, and paternal diversity of egg clutches using a comparative approach.

The host institution is a Minority-serving institution that offers two courses in arthropod biology, providing the Fellow who serves as an effective role model an opportunity to identify highly motivated students for mentoring and assisting in the research once they learn functional morphology and molecular sequencing procedures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The vast majority of animals on our planet reproduce sexually, but a small number of species have females that are known to be capable of both sexual and asexual reproduction (facultative parthenogenesis). Parthenogenesis allows females to pass on all of their genes to their offspring, which are full or partial clones, while sexual reproduction requires paternal genetic input and produces males. This means that, in the short term, we predict there to be an evolutionary advantage for parthenogens, because they do not need to find mates and they are more efficient at passing on their genes to their offspring. But what happens to males in systems where females can reproduce via both sexual reproduction and parthenogenesis? 

My research focused on two species of Japanese Opiliones (also called "daddy-longlegs" or "harvestmen") that are facultative parthenogens. I studied both their population genomics (how genomes differ between populations of one species) and the morphology of males of these species in order to understand how parthenogenesis has affected them. In order to study many genes, I learned cutting-edge techniques for DNA sequencing that are currently being employed in the life sciences. I also received training in specimen preparation, photography, teaching, and pedagogy, so that I would be better able to communicate my research findings.

I discovered that these two harvestmen species, Leiobunum manubriatum and Leiobunum globosum, are each other's closest evolutionary relatives. While many parthenogens are actually the products of hybrid crosses between two species, this does not appear to be the case with L. manubriatum and L. globosum. However, these harvestmen are similar to other parthenogens in that there appears to have been an ancient genome duplication event in the ancestral lineage of these species that means that most of L. manubriatum females and all of L. globosum males and females have twice the genome size that we would expect, which we call tetraploidy (the rest of L. manubriatum is diploid, like humans). Surprisingly, in one population of L. manubriatum, both tetraploid and diploid females occur. 

Another similarity that L. manubriatum shares with other parthenogenetic animal and plant species is that the ratio of males to females in southern populations is close to 50-50. At higher elevation and latitude, males are rarer than females, making up 5% of the population or less. When I looked at the reproductive traits of the L. manubriatum males from populations where they are very rare, I found these males had larger pedipalps (clasping appendages) than is typical for the Japanese harvestmen, even after we account for variance in size due to total body size, and due to the shared evolutionary history of the harvestmen species. This is interesting, because male harvestmen use their pedipalps to hold on to females and coerce them to mate. It is possible that in a species where females can reproduce asexually, males are under evolutionary selection pressure to be able to coerce females to mate, or they will lose reproductive opportunities altogether. My findings indicate that long-term bias in male-female ratios may play a role in how mating and morphology are shaped by evolution.

I have found Opiliones a fascinating order of non-spider arachnids to study because they are extremely abundant in the autumn season of temperate regions like Japan and eastern North America and yet, we still have so much to learn about their biology. The biodiversity of these species is not fully known, and there are pervasive myths associated with them-- particularly their supposed venomosity. My research has provided a number of opportunities to speak about the importance of basic research on biodiversity, especially in arthropods that are lesser-studied, like harvestmen. I also find parallels between need to study biodiversity and the push to improve diversity in the STEM research fields. I was funded through the Broadening Participation concentration area of the PRFB, and I believe it is imperative to work towards scientific literacy of all citizens, and a research workforce that represents today's society. To promote diversity in STEM, especially evolutionary biology, I participated in science education community outreach with my local natural history museum and science center, and I mentored two master's students and several undergraduate students through collaborative efforts.
